articles.headline: Bing, the Imitator, Often Goes Google One Better
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s rechristened search engine, Bing, makes a concerted effort to organize search results in more helpful ways than Google, and often succeeds.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s rechristened search engine, Bing, makes a concerted effort to organize search results in more helpful ways than Google, and often succeeds.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last 15 years, Microsoft’s master business plan seems to have been, “Wait until somebody else has a hit. Then copy it.”

articles.headline: Migrants Describe Grief From China’s Strife
articles.snippet: The journey of a family trying to forge a new life in the Xinjiang region ended with the death of a son in ethnic riots.
articles.abstract: The journey of a family trying to forge a new life in the Xinjiang region ended with the death of a son in ethnic riots.
articles.lead_paragraph: URUMQI, China  As young Uighurs rampaged through the streets of this western regional capital on Sunday, Zhang Aiying rushed home and stashed her fruit cart away, safe from the mob. But there was no sign of her son, who had ventured back into the chaos to retrieve another of the family’s carts.

articles.headline: Blowout Ratings for a Farewell, Online and Off
articles.snippet: On television and on the Internet, tens of millions of viewers tuned into Michael Jackson’s star-studded memorial service, making it one of the most-watched farewells in history.
articles.abstract: On television and on the Internet, tens of millions of viewers tuned into Michael Jackson’s star-studded memorial service, making it one of the most-watched farewells in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: On television and on the Internet, tens of millions of viewers tuned in to Michael Jackson’s star-studded memorial service on Tuesday, making it one of the most watched farewells in history.

articles.headline: Infighting Distracts Unions at Crucial Time
articles.snippet: The labor movement’s allies control the White House and Congress, but union leaders have been distracted by disputes.
articles.abstract: The labor movement’s allies control the White House and Congress, but union leaders have been distracted by disputes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With their allies controlling the White House and Congress, the nation’s labor unions should be making hay. Instead many unions are making war  largely with one another  in the biggest, nastiest surge of labor fratricide in decades.

articles.headline: In Chrome, Hints of a Real Rival to Windows
articles.snippet: Google promises that its Chrome operating system will put an emphasis on speed, simplicity and security.
articles.abstract: Google promises that its Chrome operating system will put an emphasis on speed, simplicity and security.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  If at times you’re frustrated with your PC  and who isn’t?  Google says it is working on a solution.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Cities Lose Out on Road Funds From Federal Stimulus
articles.snippet: A New York Times analysis found that transportation stimulus funds went disproportionately to rural areas, which advocates say could stall economic progress.
articles.abstract: A New York Times analysis found that transportation stimulus funds went disproportionately to rural areas, which advocates say could stall economic progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two-thirds of the country lives in large metropolitan areas, home to the nation’s worst traffic jams and some of its oldest roads and bridges. But cities and their surrounding regions are getting far less than two-thirds of federal transportation stimulus money.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Griff Palmer

articles.headline: U.S. Unveils More Frugal Bank Plan
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has had to adjust its plans for banks because many do not like the strings attached to government programs.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has had to adjust its plans for banks because many do not like the strings attached to government programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly a year, the question has vexed Washington and Wall Street: What do we do with all these impaired mortgage investments?
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Michael J. de la Merced
